channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Osborne to unveil extra £2.5bn cuts
item.description: The government is to announce further spending cuts in Wednesday's Budget, with the savings going to large-scale infrastructure projects designed to boost economic growth.

item.title: Wave of deadly bombings hit Baghdad
item.description: At least 48 people are killed and scores are injured in a series of bomb attacks in Baghdad on the 10th anniversary of the US-led invasion of Iraq.

item.title: Cyprus may drop tax for small savers
item.description: The Cyprus finance ministry now says bank depositors with savings under 20,000 euros (£17,000) would be exempt from a levy, amid continuing outrage over a bailout plan.

item.title: Dad 'possibly' set fatal house blaze
item.description: A mother accused of the manslaughter of her six children in a house fire tells jurors she "can't rule out" the possibility that her husband started the blaze.

item.title: Learning disability early death risk
item.description: People with learning disabilities die on average 16 years earlier than they should, due to NHS failings, according to official research.

item.title: New nuclear power plant approved
item.description: Energy Secretary Ed Davey gives the go-ahead for the first of a planned new generation of nuclear power plants in the UK.

item.title: Papacy begins with plea for poor
item.description: Pope Francis inaugurates his papacy at a Mass in Rome, calling on global leaders and all people of the world to defend the poor and the weak.

item.title: Roache apologises for abuse comments
item.description: Coronation Street star William Roache apologises after appearing to suggest sex abuse victims are paying the price for their behaviour in "previous lives" during an interview.

item.title: Joss Stone 'unaware of murder plot'
item.description: Singer Joss Stone only became aware of an alleged plot to kill her after being told by police when two men were arrested, she tells a court.

item.title: Syrian rebels 'use chemical weapon'
item.description: Syrian state media say rebels fighting to topple President Bashar al-Assad have fired a chemical weapon in the north of the country, killing 15 people.

item.title: Seven die in US arms depot explosion
item.description: Seven service personnel have died in a blast at a military ammunition storage facility in the US state of Nevada, says a Marine Corps spokesman.

item.title: 'Harassed tourist' jumps off balcony
item.description: A British woman is injured after jumping from a hotel balcony to escape from alleged harassment in Agra, India, local police say.

item.title: Internet fears over press regulation
item.description: Concerns have been expressed over the extent to which websites will be affected by a new press watchdog established by royal charter and backed by law.

item.title: Jedi 'could perform marriages'
item.description: Proposed changes to marriage would open the way for Star Wars Jedi to perform ceremonies, says a church.

item.title: BBC Worldwide sells Lonely Planet
item.description: BBC Worldwide, the commercial arm of the BBC, is to sell travel guide business Lonely Planet to US media company NC2, at a loss of nearly £80m.

item.title: Fuel costs push inflation to 2.8%
item.description: UK consumer price inflation rises to 2.8% in February thanks in part to rising energy prices, including household fuel bills.

item.title: Ryanair in new expansion drive
item.description: Ryanair is planning to increase its aircraft fleet by a third to 400 planes after ordering 175 planes from Boeing.

item.title: Childcare plan 'better for parents'
item.description: The government has promised to create a "better" childcare system for parents, by allowing them to claim back up to £1,200 a year in costs per child.

item.title: Boris Johnson 'would like to be PM'
item.description: In a forthcoming BBC documentary, Mayor of London Boris Johnson admits he would like to be prime minister, but insists "it's not going to happen".

item.title: Care costs cap 'will cause disputes'
item.description: Introducing a cap on elderly care costs in England could leave councils open to a "deluge of disputes and legal challenges", MPs and peers are warning.

item.title: NHS 'had culture of sheer bullying'
item.description: The former boss of a hospital which is being investigated over high death rates tells MPs there was a culture of "sheer bullying" in the NHS.

item.title: Parents fined for truanting children
item.description: A rising number of parents in England have been fined for allowing their children to miss school, figures show.

item.title: 'Mismatch' on teenagers' job hopes
item.description: There is a "massive mismatch" between young people's career expectations and the reality of the jobs available, a major survey of teenagers suggests.

item.title: Activists switch on net 'bat signal'
item.description: Activists switch on an internet signalling system to help co-ordinate protests about a draft law in the US.

item.title: US hacker jailed over AT&T attack
item.description: A US 'hacktivist' who broke into AT&T's network and stole contact details for 120,000 iPad owners has been given a 41 month jail sentence.

item.title: White Mars rock dazzles scientists
item.description: A rock crushed under the Curiosity Mars rover's wheels has dazzled mission scientists with its brilliant white interior.

item.title: Ladder link helps voles get out more
item.description: Isolated water voles in London are given miniature ladders to encourage them to venture further afield.

item.title: Bowie tickets fastest-selling for V&A
item.description: The upcoming David Bowie exhibition at London's V&A museum is the fastest-selling in the museum's history.

item.title: Tests on Hockney assistant's body
item.description: It could be several weeks before the cause of death of David Hockney's assistant is known, police say.

item.title: The African chief converted to Christianity by Dr Livingstone
item.description: The story of Sechele, African chief and Dr Livingstone's 'only' convert, is as fascinating as that of the missionary himself.

item.title: Richard O'Brien: ‘I'm 70% man'
item.description: Is Rocky Horror writer Richard O'Brien normal for thinking himself a "third sex" between male and female?

item.title: Owen to retire at end of season
item.description: Former England striker Michael Owen announces he is to retire from football at the end of the season.

item.title: Blackburn sack manager Appleton
item.description: Blackburn Rovers sack manager Michael Appleton after just 15 games and 67 days in charge at Ewood Park.

item.title: McManaman escapes charge from FA
item.description: Wigan's Callum McManaman will not be charged by the Football Association over his tackle on Newcastle's Massadio Haidara.

item.title: Wales have to 'kick on' - Jones
item.description: Prop Adam Jones wants Wales to start beating the best teams in the world after retaining the Six Nations title.

item.title: England draft in Taylor for Cahill
item.description: England call up Newcastle's Steven Taylor after Gary Cahill is ruled out of the World Cup qualifier against San Marino.

item.title: Veteran given first Arctic Star
item.description: A campaigner who fought for recognition for Arctic convoy veterans becomes the first recipient of a new medal.

item.title: Barbados shooting: Two men arrested
item.description: Two men are arrested in connection with the shooting of a married couple from Suffolk while on a cruise holiday in Barbados.

item.title: Schools closed as snow hits Scotland
item.description: More than 100 schools are closed after heavy snow affected parts of Scotland, with whiteout conditions in some areas making driving difficult.

item.title: Accused denies missing Lynda murder
item.description: One of two men accused of murdering missing businesswoman Lynda Spence denies killing her or entering a flat where she was allegedly tortured.

item.title: '180 hospital beds' to close in NI
item.description: One hundred and eighty hospital beds are to close in a major reform of the health service in Northern Ireland, the BBC understands.

item.title: New prison set for Magilligan site
item.description: A new jail is to be built on the current site of Magilligan prison near Limavady, Justice Minister David Ford announces.

item.title: School trip host family ban approved
item.description: A ban on letting children on school exchange trips stay with host families abroad due to safety fears is approved.

item.title: Drink-drive AM's reprimand row tears
item.description: A Welsh assembly member breaks down in tears in the chamber as she defends her absence from a meeting where she was reprimanded for drink-driving.

item.title: ICC hails 'Terminator' surrender
item.description: The International Criminal Court welcomes the surrender in Rwanda of war crimes suspect Bosco Ntaganda, a Congolese rebel known as "The Terminator".

item.title: Zimbabwe approves new constitution
item.description: Zimbabwe's new constitution was approved by an overwhelming majority in Saturday's referendum, the electoral commission says.

item.title: Fukushima power 'partially restored'
item.description: Cooling systems to spent fuel ponds at Japan's Fukushima nuclear plant have been partially restored after a power failure, operator Tepco says.

item.title: 'Deterrent' US B-52s fly in S Korea
item.description: The US is flying nuclear-capable B-52 bombers over South Korea, in what it says is a response to escalating North Korean rhetoric.

item.title: Bulgarian Roma killed in shooting
item.description: A Bulgarian former army officer shoots dead three members of a Roma family who lived next door to him, before turning the gun on himself, police say.

item.title: Russia shelves Magnitsky probe
item.description: Detectives in Russia drop their investigation into the death in prison of lawyer Sergei Magnitsky, saying there is no evidence of a crime.

item.title: Rains cause deadly Brazil landslides
item.description: At least 16 people are killed in landslides in a mountainous area north of Rio de Janeiro, after heavy rains.

item.title: HSBC in new money laundering claims
item.description: Banking giant HSBC, which was hit with a US fine for money laundering last year, is facing fresh accusations of illegal activity in Argentina.

item.title: Jordan's king slams region's leaders
item.description: Jordan's King Abdullah II says Egypt's President Morsi has "no depth" of understanding of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, in a US interview.

item.title: Gaddafi cousin arrested in Egypt
item.description: Egyptian police in Cairo arrest Ahmed Gaddaf al-Dam, a close aide and cousin of the late Libyan leader, Col Muammar Gaddafi.

item.title: Man guilty of Irish woman's murder
item.description: An American has been found guilty of the murder of Irish student Nicola Furlong in Tokyo last May.

item.title: Obama: Iran must 'reduce tensions'
item.description: President Obama offers Iran a "practical solution" if it seeks peaceful nuclear capabilities rather than weapons, in a video marking Persian new year.

item.title: Day in pictures: 19 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 19 March

item.title: In Pictures: The career of Frank Thornton
item.description: A look at the career of the Are You Being Served?

item.title: Day in pictures: 18 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 18 March

item.title: In pictures: India's Parsis
item.description: India's ancient Parsi community, on show in Mumbai

item.title: Week in pictures: 9-15 March 2013
item.description: A selection of the best news photos

item.title: In pictures: Red Nose in space
item.description: A Comic Relief red nose is launched into space

item.title: Day in pictures: 15 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 15 March

item.title: In pictures: HMS Belfast at 75
item.description: HMS Belfast celebrates its 75th anniversary

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: MPs are taking all stages of the Jobseekers (Back to Work Schemes) Bill.

item.title: VIDEO: Cannabis-scented cards sent to homes
item.description: Hundreds of people are being sent marijuana-scented scratch and sniff cards to help them recognise the smell of illegal cannabis farms and alert the police.

item.title: VIDEO: PM ambitions 'like picking up loose ball'
item.description: Boris Johnson has admitted that he would like to be prime minister but insists "it's not going to happen"

item.title: VIDEO: MPs throw punches in parliament
item.description: Ukraine's parliament was suspended for a short period after fighting erupted among MPs from the president's party and a far-right opposition faction, over a speech made in Russian.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Ageing' drinking app goes global
item.description: A phone app that shows how you age when you drink becomes such a global success it is downloaded almost half a million times.

item.title: VIDEO: The chancellor's challenges
item.description: Chancellor George Osborne has some tough decisions to take because the economy has not been growing. So what is the right way to encourage that growth - borrowing more or cutting spending?

item.title: VIDEO: Chinese Girl portrait up for auction
item.description: Vladimir Tretchikoff's original painting of the Chinese Girl, believed to be the world's most reproduced print, is to go on sale in London.

item.title: VIDEO: Snow closes schools and disrupts travel
item.description: More than 100 schools close in Scotland following Met Office warnings of heavy snow and gale force winds.

item.title: AUDIO: How I lost my £1.8m lottery winnings
item.description: Lottery winner Roger Griffiths told BBC Radio 5 live how he became rich overnight and then lost it all when the financial crisis hit the UK.

item.title: John Simpson: 'The Iraq memories I can't rid myself of'
item.description: John Simpson on the memory that won't leave him

item.title: Can you accidentally do a Nazi salute?
item.description: How easy is it to accidentally do a Nazi salute?

item.title: What does a pope do?
item.description: What exactly does a pope's job entail?

item.title: Michael Owen: A career in pictures
item.description: Footballer Michael Owen from teenage debut to retirement

item.title: UK's Afghan war effectively over
item.description: UK combat operations are effectively over, Mark Urban hears

item.title: Sweden's night nurseries
item.description: The toddlers who go to night nursery while their parents work

item.title: In pictures: Sony World Photography Awards
item.description: Winners of the 2013 World Photography Awards

item.title: Press reform: Media reaction to regulation deal
item.description: Media reaction to plans for press regulation

item.title: Q&A: Childcare vouchers plan
item.description: Who will benefit from childcare vouchers plan?

item.title: Zoe – Cambridge’s emotional talking head
item.description: Rory Cellan-Jones encounters an emotional talking head

item.title: Damage limitation in Cyprus
item.description: Cyprus deal looks like mistake, says Stephanie Flanders
